title.value: Surrogate Minimization: An Optimization Algorithm for Training Large Neural Networks with Model Parallelism
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Surrogate Minimization: An Optimization Algorithm for Training Large Neural Networks with Model Parallelism

extractions.description: This paper proposes the Surrogate Minimization (SM) algorithm which is designed to optimize large, memory-intensive neural networks by distributing their layers across multiple GPUs. The algorithm efficiently minimizes a global loss by parallelizing the training using layer-wise local losses, in conjunction with GPipe for pipelining. Theoretical convergence guarantees and empirical results on MLPs demonstrate the superiority of the SM algorithm over existing methods.

type.justification: The paper includes experimental results on MLPs and provides empirical evidence that the proposed SM algorithm outperforms existing baseline methods.
type.quote: Finally, our experimental results on MLPs demonstrate that SM leads to faster convergence compared to competitive baselines.

name.justification: The main focus of the paper is on developing an optimization algorithm to improve the training efficiency of large neural networks using model parallelism.
name.quote: Optimizing large memory-intensive neural networks requires distributing its layers across multiple GPUs (referred to as model parallelism).

name.justification: The paper specifically focuses on optimizing neural networks through model parallelism by distributing layers across GPUs.
name.quote: Optimizing large memory-intensive neural networks requires distributing its layers across multiple GPUs (referred to as model parallelism).

name.justification: The focus is on training neural networks more efficiently using a new optimization algorithm.
name.quote: We propose the Surrogate Minimization (SM) algorithm. SM allows for multiple parallel updates to the layer-wise parameters of a distributed neural network and consequently improves the GPU utilization of GPipe.

name.justification: The paper empirically evaluates the SM algorithm using Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs) on the MNIST dataset.
name.quote: Finally, our experimental results on MLPs demonstrate that SM leads to faster convergence compared to competitive baselines.

is_contributed.justification: MLPs are a well-known type of neural network and are not introduced as a new contribution in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We compare SM with various baselines using 2, 4, and 8 layers of MLP on the MNIST [9] dataset in the deterministic setting.

is_executed.justification: The experimental results on MLPs were run on GPUs.
is_executed.quote: For the experiments involving 4 and 8 layers of MLP, we distribute the layers equally among 4 GPUs. All experiments presented here use the Nvidia Tesla V100 GPU (16 GB memory) and Intel Xeon Gold 6126 CPU (2.60GHz).

is_compared.justification: The performance of MLPs using the SM algorithm is compared against various baselines.
is_compared.quote: Finally, our experimental results on MLPs demonstrate that SM leads to faster convergence compared to competitive baselines.
